            "timestamp": 1706077463000,
            "title": "Uma Protocol Introduced Oval Allows DeFi Protocols to Capture Oracle Extractable Value",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, blockchain project Uma has rolled out a solution called Oval, which aims to allow DeFi protocols to capture value that emerges during oracle updates by tapping into what’s known as oracle extractable value — a type of MEV generated when protocols request price updates from an oracle.</p><p>MEV involves extracting value by manipulating transaction order in a block on the Ethereum network, often with the aid of automated bots. This type of MEV arises either from the lack of liquidity across different decentralized exchanges or from their front-running each other under certain market conditions.</p><p>There is one type of MEV related to oracles, as Uma notes. In the decentralized finance niche — and in protocols such as lending or borrowing — oracles are crucial as they provide external data, like price feeds, to smart contracts. When an oracle update occurs, such as a price feed update, it can create MEV opportunities. For instance, if a lending protocol relies on an oracle for the latest asset prices, there may be a brief window post-update where a trader can leverage this information before the market responds.</p><p>“MEV is a major issue for Ethereum, with tens of millions of dollars extracted every year. OEV accounts for a big chunk of that because protocols need price updates,” Uma co-founder Hart Lambur said. “Oval addresses a real problem by helping protocols capture OEV. It’s been a privilege to work with Flashbots’ best-in-class team to bring Oval to mainnet.”</p><p>Oval's goal is to enable protocols, such as lending, to utilize this solution to retain and profit from this value rather than losing it to bots. In this setup, MEV searchers participate in an auction system, bidding for the right to access data from Chainlink oracles related to a certain protocol. The auction proceeds then benefit the protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/oval.png",

            "title": "Radiant Capital Loses $4.5M in Exploit, Halts Lending Market on Arbitrum",
            "content": "<p>Radiant Capital, the lending protocol on Arbitrum, has temporarily halted its lending and borrowing markets after an exploit resulted in a $4.5 million loss in one of its newly launched USDC markets.</p><p>Blockchain security firm PeckShield has identified the root cause of the exploit, which involves a hacker taking advantage of a time window during the activation of a new market within Radiant Capital's lending protocol. The protocol is a fork of the popular lending platforms Compound and Aave. The exploit also relies on a known rounding issue present in the current codebase of Compound and Aave. By exploiting this vulnerability, the attacker was able to profit through repeated deposit and withdrawal operations.</p><p>Marc \"Chainsaw\" Zeller, a core member of Aave, commented on the situation, stating that Aave had already identified the issue and implemented safety measures to fully mitigate it several weeks ago. He criticized many Aave forks for merely copying the code without adopting the robust safety culture of Aave.</p>",

            "timestamp": 1703673351000,
            "title": "Hong Kong Releases Consultation Paper to Regulate Stablecoins",
            "content": "<p>Hong Kong has released a consultation paper to regulate fiat-referenced stablecoin, with issuers will need to obtain a specific local license. The consultation paper is published today by the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.</p><p>The consultation period for the proposal begins today and will run until February 29, 2024. The proposal outlines the definition of fiat-referenced stablecoins and introduces a requirement for companies that actively promote the issuance of such stablecoins to the public of Hong Kong to obtain a license from the HKMA.</p><p>To obtain an HKMA license, companies will need to meet specific criteria. This includes ensuring that all circulating stablecoins are fully backed by reserves that are at least equal to their par value. Additionally, the proposal emphasizes the need for segregation and safekeeping of reserve assets, as well as regular disclosure and reporting. It is important to note that algorithmic stablecoins will not be eligible for a license under these regulations.</p><p>Furthermore, stablecoin issuers will be required to establish a registered office in Hong Kong and have a chief executive, senior management team, and key personnel in place.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/hk_stables.jpg",

          {
            "timestamp": 1706077463000,
            "title": "Uma Protocol Introduced Oval Allows DeFi Protocols to Capture Oracle Extractable Value",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, blockchain project Uma has rolled out a solution called Oval, which aims to allow DeFi protocols to capture value that emerges during oracle updates by tapping into what’s known as oracle extractable value — a type of MEV generated when protocols request price updates from an oracle.</p><p>MEV involves extracting value by manipulating transaction order in a block on the Ethereum network, often with the aid of automated bots. This type of MEV arises either from the lack of liquidity across different decentralized exchanges or from their front-running each other under certain market conditions.</p><p>There is one type of MEV related to oracles, as Uma notes. In the decentralized finance niche — and in protocols such as lending or borrowing — oracles are crucial as they provide external data, like price feeds, to smart contracts. When an oracle update occurs, such as a price feed update, it can create MEV opportunities. For instance, if a lending protocol relies on an oracle for the latest asset prices, there may be a brief window post-update where a trader can leverage this information before the market responds.</p><p>“MEV is a major issue for Ethereum, with tens of millions of dollars extracted every year. OEV accounts for a big chunk of that because protocols need price updates,” Uma co-founder Hart Lambur said. “Oval addresses a real problem by helping protocols capture OEV. It’s been a privilege to work with Flashbots’ best-in-class team to bring Oval to mainnet.”</p><p>Oval's goal is to enable protocols, such as lending, to utilize this solution to retain and profit from this value rather than losing it to bots. In this setup, MEV searchers participate in an auction system, bidding for the right to access data from Chainlink oracles related to a certain protocol. The auction proceeds then benefit the protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/oval.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/uma-protocol-introduced-oval-allows-defi-protocols-to-capture-oracle-extractable-value?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="

          {
            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",

            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, re-staking protocol EigenLayer plans to adopt a \"shared security\" system, a mechanism allowing protocols to join the network by leveraging a common pool of ETH stakes.</p><p>EigenLayer offers a protocol for users to deposit and \"re-stake\" ether from various liquid staking tokens, aiming to allocate those funds to secure third-party networks. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism. This would make it economically unviable for an attacker to take down any given protocol.</p>",

          {
            "timestamp": 1684481389000,
            "title": "Osmosis, Axelar and Akash Introduce Mesh Security Model Lets Chains Secure Each Other",
            "content": "<p><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/osmosis/overview\">Osmosis</a> leads the development of a new security model called \"mesh security\" in the Cosmos ecosystem. The project is funded by Osmosis, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/axelar/overview\">Axelar</a>, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/akash-networkakt/overview\">Akash</a> Network, and ATOM Accelerator DAO, and aims to consolidate the value of validator stakes from multiple blockchains to increase security against potential breaches or staking takeovers.</p><p>Mesh security allows Cosmos chains to consolidate their token security. This leads to significantly higher economic security than what a single chain can offer. Validators will have the option to re-stake their bonded tokens to their chosen validators on a partnering chain, similar to the Eigen Layer model on Ethereum.</p><blockquote><p>“With the introduction of mesh security, we can approach security bidirectionally, meaning that two chains, like Osmosis and Juno for example, can provide security to each other,” Sunny Aggarwal, co-founder of Osmosis Labs said.</p></blockquote><p>The development will proceed in three phases, with contributions from teams across the Cosmos ecosystem and an expected final launch in Q1 2024.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/cryptocurrencies\">TokenInsight</a> is dedicated to covering the most important and cutting-edge trends in the world of crypto. If you have information to share with us, please feel free to contact our email <a href=\"mailto:news@tokeninsight.com\">news@tokeninsight.com</a>. Your trust will be well respected.</p>",

            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",

        "related_news": [
          {
            "timestamp": 1706077463000,
            "title": "Uma Protocol Introduced Oval Allows DeFi Protocols to Capture Oracle Extractable Value",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, blockchain project Uma has rolled out a solution called Oval, which aims to allow DeFi protocols to capture value that emerges during oracle updates by tapping into what’s known as oracle extractable value — a type of MEV generated when protocols request price updates from an oracle.</p><p>MEV involves extracting value by manipulating transaction order in a block on the Ethereum network, often with the aid of automated bots. This type of MEV arises either from the lack of liquidity across different decentralized exchanges or from their front-running each other under certain market conditions.</p><p>There is one type of MEV related to oracles, as Uma notes. In the decentralized finance niche — and in protocols such as lending or borrowing — oracles are crucial as they provide external data, like price feeds, to smart contracts. When an oracle update occurs, such as a price feed update, it can create MEV opportunities. For instance, if a lending protocol relies on an oracle for the latest asset prices, there may be a brief window post-update where a trader can leverage this information before the market responds.</p><p>“MEV is a major issue for Ethereum, with tens of millions of dollars extracted every year. OEV accounts for a big chunk of that because protocols need price updates,” Uma co-founder Hart Lambur said. “Oval addresses a real problem by helping protocols capture OEV. It’s been a privilege to work with Flashbots’ best-in-class team to bring Oval to mainnet.”</p><p>Oval's goal is to enable protocols, such as lending, to utilize this solution to retain and profit from this value rather than losing it to bots. In this setup, MEV searchers participate in an auction system, bidding for the right to access data from Chainlink oracles related to a certain protocol. The auction proceeds then benefit the protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/oval.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/uma-protocol-introduced-oval-allows-defi-protocols-to-capture-oracle-extractable-value?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="

The launch marks the completion of Frax’s v3 roadmap, deploying all its new features.</p><p>“FXBs are a way to buy future FRAX stablecoins at a particular timestamp for a discount today,” said the team.             "title": "Liquid Restaking Protocol EtherFi Launched Vampire Attack Strategy",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Defiant, Liquid restaking protocol EtherFi has launched ‘deVamp’ in a bid to incentivize users to swap their existing Eigenlayer deposits for its eETH liquid restaking token (LRT).</p><p>Users that restaked Lido’s stETH, Coinbase’s cbETH, and Binance’s wBETH on Eigenlayer can now instantly swap their deposits into liquid eETH, avoiding the 7-day delay on withdrawals put in place by the highly anticipated restaking protocol.</p><p>With deVamp, users will receive 3,000 loyalty points per restaked ETH migrated into eETH.</p><p>Additionally, holders of these liquid staking tokens (LSTs) can swap them for eETH and earn points on the deVamp website. Traders will be exempt from paying trading fees and earn 2,000 points per ETH.</p><p>Participants in deVamp will receive Vamp Badges, whereas those trying to game the system by depositing and immediately withdrawing will receive a sad pepe Quitter badge with a penalty of 4,000 points upon withdrawal.</p>",

          {
            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/8-ethereum-validators-went-down-on-sunday-sparking-worries-on-client-diversity?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          },

            "timestamp": 1705977114000,
            "title": "EigenLayer Plans Shared Security Model, Re-stakes to be Used For All Network Services",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, re-staking protocol EigenLayer plans to adopt a \"shared security\" system, a mechanism allowing protocols to join the network by leveraging a common pool of ETH stakes.</p><p>EigenLayer offers a protocol for users to deposit and \"re-stake\" ether from various liquid staking tokens, aiming to allocate those funds to secure third-party networks. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism. This would make it economically unviable for an attacker to take down any given protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/EL.png",

            "title": "Circle Claims Stablecoins Aren't Securities in Amicus Curiae Brief of SEC-Binance Case",
            "content": "<p><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/usd-coin/overview\">$USDC</a> issuer Circle has filed its amicus curiae brief of the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) suing <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/exchanges/binance\">Binance</a> case, arguing that stablecoins, such as $USDC and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/binance-usd/overview\">$BUSD</a>, are not securities.</p><p>In June, the SEC sued Binance and CZ, alleging the exchange unlawfully offered and sold unregistered securities, including $BUSD. But Circle claimed that stablecoins can't constitute securities, partly because the buyers don't expect any profit from standalone purchases.</p><p>In the filing, Circle said that the payment sablecoins themselves don't have the essential features of an investment contract, thus don't belong to the SEC's jurisdiction.</p><p>Related: <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/key-points-on-the-sec-s-lawsuit-against-binance-and-cz\">Key Points on the SEC's Lawsuit Against Binance and CZ</a></p><p><img src=\"https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/calendar/img20230929025745f73cfd8c-edde-4268-b2fb-94da2a6c60fe.jpg\"></p><p>Stay updated with the most important <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/news\">cryptocurrency news</a> and valuable insights, conveniently delivered to your email every day. <a rel=\"noopener noreferrer nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://mailchi.mp/tokeninsight/newsletter\">Subscribe to the TokenInsight mailing list now!</a></p><p>Prefer social media?             "timestamp": 1678416204000,
            "title": "Aave DAO Votes to Remove Binance's $BUSD From Its Lending Platform",
            "content": "<p>Decentralized lending protocol <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/aave/overview\">Aave</a> has taken a step towards delisting Binance's troubled stablecoin $<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/binance-usd/overview\">BUSD</a>. Aave's decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) voted in favor of a proposal to increase the cost of borrowing $BUSD and decrease the revenue earned by its lenders.</p><p>The measures are intended to discourage the use of $BUSD on Aave's platform. The vote comes amid regulatory uncertainty around Binance's dollar-pegged stablecoin, which has led to several market participants distancing themselves from it.</p><p><img src=\"https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/calendar/img2023031010410221d976bd-797e-4a77-bfb3-67e4678cbcb1.jpg\"></p><p>The author of the proposal, Marc Zeller, stated:</p><blockquote><p>the circulating supply of $BUSD will gradually trend towards zero over time, making it necessary to offboard the stablecoin.</p></blockquote><p>Aave froze its $BUSD markets ahead of the on-chain vote. The final stage of the governance process will involve changes to the smart contracts controlling borrowing and lending.</p><p>Aave held approximately $11 million in $BUSD liquidity from lenders and had $7.6 million in $BUSD loaned out. Zeller urged Aave users to switch to other stablecoins on the platform. Aave's proposal garnered overwhelming support from its DAO members, indicating a consensus to move away from $BUSD.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/cryptocurrencies\">TokenInsight</a> is dedicated to covering the most valuable news in the world of crypto. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism. This would make it economically unviable for an attacker to take down any given protocol.</p>",

          {
            "timestamp": 1706077463000,
            "title": "Uma Protocol Introduced Oval Allows DeFi Protocols to Capture Oracle Extractable Value",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, blockchain project Uma has rolled out a solution called Oval, which aims to allow DeFi protocols to capture value that emerges during oracle updates by tapping into what’s known as oracle extractable value — a type of MEV generated when protocols request price updates from an oracle.</p><p>MEV involves extracting value by manipulating transaction order in a block on the Ethereum network, often with the aid of automated bots. This type of MEV arises either from the lack of liquidity across different decentralized exchanges or from their front-running each other under certain market conditions.</p><p>There is one type of MEV related to oracles, as Uma notes. In the decentralized finance niche — and in protocols such as lending or borrowing — oracles are crucial as they provide external data, like price feeds, to smart contracts. When an oracle update occurs, such as a price feed update, it can create MEV opportunities. For instance, if a lending protocol relies on an oracle for the latest asset prices, there may be a brief window post-update where a trader can leverage this information before the market responds.</p><p>“MEV is a major issue for Ethereum, with tens of millions of dollars extracted every year. OEV accounts for a big chunk of that because protocols need price updates,” Uma co-founder Hart Lambur said. “Oval addresses a real problem by helping protocols capture OEV. It’s been a privilege to work with Flashbots’ best-in-class team to bring Oval to mainnet.”</p><p>Oval's goal is to enable protocols, such as lending, to utilize this solution to retain and profit from this value rather than losing it to bots. In this setup, MEV searchers participate in an auction system, bidding for the right to access data from Chainlink oracles related to a certain protocol. The auction proceeds then benefit the protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/oval.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/uma-protocol-introduced-oval-allows-defi-protocols-to-capture-oracle-extractable-value?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="

            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",

According to TokenInsight's analysis, the project's social media lacks upgrades, and there are concerns about the project's operation status.</p><ul><li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/lemonchainlemc2/overview\"><strong>LEMONCHAIN ($LEMC)</strong></a>: Downgraded from CCC Stable to CC Stable.</li></ul><p>The downgrade of $LEMC's rating can be attributed primarily to its roadmap &amp; progress and secondary market indicators. According to TokenInsight's analysis, the project lacks development progress synchronization with the community, and there are concerns about the sustainability of the project's services.</p><h2>About TokenInsight and Rating Methodology</h2><p>TokenInsight is an indicators-driven blockchain institution that provides market intelligence through ratings, industry research, and data analysis. Our rating methodology utilizes standardized criteria, combining quantitative and qualitative analysis to ensure objective and consistent evaluations.           },
          {
            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/8-ethereum-validators-went-down-on-sunday-sparking-worries-on-client-diversity?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          },
          {
            "timestamp": 1705977114000,
            "title": "EigenLayer Plans Shared Security Model, Re-stakes to be Used For All Network Services",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, re-staking protocol EigenLayer plans to adopt a \"shared security\" system, a mechanism allowing protocols to join the network by leveraging a common pool of ETH stakes.</p><p>EigenLayer offers a protocol for users to deposit and \"re-stake\" ether from various liquid staking tokens, aiming to allocate those funds to secure third-party networks. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism. This would make it economically unviable for an attacker to take down any given protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/EL.png",

            "content": "<p>NFT aggregation marketplace <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/rarible/overview\">Rarible</a> announced it will stop aggregating orders from OpenSea, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/looksrare/overview\">LooksRare</a>, and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/x2y2/overview\">X2Y2</a>, because it supports royalties, while all the three marketplaces mentioned use optional royalties.</p><p>\"The principle of royalties is at the heart of decentralization—a continual affirmation of a creator's value in every transaction.           {
            "timestamp": 1706077463000,
            "title": "Uma Protocol Introduced Oval Allows DeFi Protocols to Capture Oracle Extractable Value",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, blockchain project Uma has rolled out a solution called Oval, which aims to allow DeFi protocols to capture value that emerges during oracle updates by tapping into what’s known as oracle extractable value — a type of MEV generated when protocols request price updates from an oracle.</p><p>MEV involves extracting value by manipulating transaction order in a block on the Ethereum network, often with the aid of automated bots. This type of MEV arises either from the lack of liquidity across different decentralized exchanges or from their front-running each other under certain market conditions.</p><p>There is one type of MEV related to oracles, as Uma notes. In the decentralized finance niche — and in protocols such as lending or borrowing — oracles are crucial as they provide external data, like price feeds, to smart contracts. When an oracle update occurs, such as a price feed update, it can create MEV opportunities. For instance, if a lending protocol relies on an oracle for the latest asset prices, there may be a brief window post-update where a trader can leverage this information before the market responds.</p><p>“MEV is a major issue for Ethereum, with tens of millions of dollars extracted every year. OEV accounts for a big chunk of that because protocols need price updates,” Uma co-founder Hart Lambur said. “Oval addresses a real problem by helping protocols capture OEV. It’s been a privilege to work with Flashbots’ best-in-class team to bring Oval to mainnet.”</p><p>Oval's goal is to enable protocols, such as lending, to utilize this solution to retain and profit from this value rather than losing it to bots. In this setup, MEV searchers participate in an auction system, bidding for the right to access data from Chainlink oracles related to a certain protocol. The auction proceeds then benefit the protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/oval.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/uma-protocol-introduced-oval-allows-defi-protocols-to-capture-oracle-extractable-value?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="

            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",

            "content": "<p>Stars Arena, a friend.tech-like SocialFi app on <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/avalanche/overview\">Avalanche</a>, announced it has secured the resources to close the gap caused by the previous exploit, and its smart contract will be re-opened after a full security audit.</p><p>Previously, a security hole was found in the Stars Arena contract. Though the team said the issue had been fixed, it was exploited yesterday, and around $3 million was stolen. After the incident, the crypto community suspected that it was a rug pull, and some people questioned the relationship between the project and Avalanche. But Stars Arena said, \"A special white hat development team is coming in to rapidly review the security of the platform. We will re-open the contract with all the funds in full after a full security audit. This will happen very soon.\" adding, \"We're not going anywhere.\"</p><p>Emin Gün Sirer, founder of Avalanche, also expressed his support for the project. He clarified that the project was built by the Builder and the Arena team, and it was \"a fantastic product that has proven its virality in the market.\" The losses were \"only $3m\", and he was \"confident that the hole will be plugged\".</p><p>He said, \"Stars Arena is a profitable service that makes money. The amount lost, $3m, is something that SA can recover in about 10 days or so. Worst case, the team can borrow $3m and pay it back with interest.</p><p>\"Remember that Wormhole got hacked for $300m and is still around. Axie Infinity lost $625m and is still around.           },
          {
            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/8-ethereum-validators-went-down-on-sunday-sparking-worries-on-client-diversity?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          },

            "title": "EigenLayer Plans Shared Security Model, Re-stakes to be Used For All Network Services",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, re-staking protocol EigenLayer plans to adopt a \"shared security\" system, a mechanism allowing protocols to join the network by leveraging a common pool of ETH stakes.</p><p>EigenLayer offers a protocol for users to deposit and \"re-stake\" ether from various liquid staking tokens, aiming to allocate those funds to secure third-party networks. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism. This would make it economically unviable for an attacker to take down any given protocol.</p>",

            "content": "<p>Reported Cointelegraph, at least five Ethereum liquid staking providers have either imposed or are working to impose a self-limit rule in which they promise not to own more than 22% of the Ethereum staking market — seen as a move to ensure the Ethereum network remains decentralized.</p><p>Among the Ethereum staking providers either already committed or are working to commit to the self-limit rule include <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/rocket-pool/overview\">Rocket Pool</a>, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/stakewise/overview\">StakeWise</a>, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/stader/overview\">Stader</a> Labs and Diva Staking, according to Ethereum core developer Superphiz.</p><p>Puffer Finance, another liquid staking service, also announced its commitment to the self-limit.</p><p>The proposal presumably aims to address concerns of Ethereum staking becoming increasingly centralized.</p><p>Interestingly, the largest Ethereum liquid staking provider, Lido Finance, voted by a 99.81% majority not to self-limit back last June.</p><p><img src=\"https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/calendar/img20230901034523455be87a-5df3-41d8-8810-74c0a63028a5.jpg\"></p><p>Stay updated with the most important <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/news\">cryptocurrency news</a> and valuable insights, conveniently delivered to your email every day. <a rel=\"noopener noreferrer nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://mailchi.mp/tokeninsight/newsletter\">Subscribe to the TokenInsight mailing list now!</a></p><p>Prefer social media?             "title": "$ETH Liquid Staking Protocols Gaining Momentum as Shanghai Upgrade Getting Closer",
            "content": "<p>One of the observations of early 2023 is that many <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/zh/coins/ethereum/overview\">$ETH</a> liquid staking protocols are on a good run. The Shanghai upgrade is arguably the most important milestone for Ethereum to achieve this year, and it's only about three months away. The upgrade will enable the withdrawals of staked $ETH, which is thought to be a bullish sign for $ETH liquid staking solutions.</p><p>On January 2nd, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/lido-dao-token/overview\">Lido</a>, the biggest liquid staking protocol, overtook <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/makerdao/overview\">Maker</a> to become the DeFi protocol with the highest TVL. It has maintained its position since then. Over the last seven days, the price of $LDO has gone up by 63%. Currently, Lido occupies the $ETH staking market, with a market share of over 29%.</p><p>The performance of other liquid staking protocols' tokens also reflects what's trendy. <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/rocket-pool/overview\">Rocket Pool </a>($RPL), <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/zh/coins/stakewise/overview\">StakeWise</a> ($SWISE), <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/zh/coins/ankr/overview\">Ankr</a> ($ANKR) and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/zh/coins/frax-share/overview\">Frax</a> ($FXS) all enjoyed more than 20% rises during the last week. <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/stader/overview\">Stader</a> ($SD), which was first built on Terra and plans to launch its $ETH liquid staking derivative (LSD) $ETHx, has gone rocket high with a 124% increase.</p><p><img src=\"https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/calendar/img202301090600177b49298f-335d-4453-9ac8-6686a211ba1f.jpg\"></p><p>The attention drawn to the liquid staking market doesn't come from nowhere. In the first All Core Developers call in 2023, Ethereum developers reiterated that the <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/ethereum-developers-plan-to-launch-public-testnets-for-shanghai-upgrade-in-february-mainnet-in-march\">Shanghai upgrade</a> is scheduled for sometime in March. In addition, a public testnet will be launched in February. So far, not delaying the Shanghai upgrade is the top priority for Ethereum developers.</p><p>Compared with some other major Layer1 chains, the staking ratio of $ETH is very low. Only 13.24% of the $ETH supply is being staked, whilst the staking ratio of <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/cardano/overview\">$ADA</a> and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/solana/overview\">$SOL</a> are over 70%. One of the reasons that stops people from staking $ETH is the lack of ability to unstake. This will not be a problem after the Shanghai upgrade, which will mitigate the risks of staking.</p><p>For liquid staking solutions, they need to deal with another challenge prior to the enabling of staked $ETH withdrawals, which is to keep their LSD pegged to $ETH. In Blockworks' year-in-review of 2022, researcher <a rel=\"noopener noreferrer nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.blockworksresearch.com/research/2022-year-end-review-protocol-highlights#liquid-staking\">Dan Smith</a> said, \"one of the issues for staking derivatives throughout this year (2022), primarily $stETH, has been the ability to keep price parity with $ETH due to the inability to directly arbitrage via withdrawals. This (the Shanghai upgrade) should therefore help alleviate price concerns while also giving users the ability to obtain their $ETH if they so choose.\" This also explains why liquid staking protocols benefit from the upgrade.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/lsd1.jpeg",

            "title": "Aptos to Unlock $103 Million $APT Tokens to Team and Investors in November",
            "content": "<p>According to TokenUnlocks, Layer 1 public chain <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/coins/aptos/overview\">Aptos</a> will unlock 20 million $APT tokens (worth about $103 million) on November 12 at 0:00 UTC, which is equivalent to more than 8.5% of the $APT circulating supply of 235.02 million. This will be the first time the unlocking will be in front of teams and investors.</p><figure class=\"image\"><img src=\"https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/calendar/img20230914044904400e0d56-16db-4cbb-8a4e-bb4763cd2b27.jpg\"></figure><p>The number of $APT tokens unlocked in November equaled 112% of the average daily trading volume over the past 30 days, research firm The Tie said. The firm said earlier this year that unlocks that free up liquidity, or those that represent over 100% of the average daily volume, tend to weigh over prices.</p><p>These unlocks will occur on a monthly basis and will coincide with the monthly staking reward unlocks (5.83 million $APT or 32% of daily average volume, which will increase to 6.15 million $APT in December). In addition, 4.62 million $APT has been unlocked to communities and foundations each month since last year,\" The Tie said.</p><p><img src=\"https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/calendar/img20230914045013615b50f7-dde2-4a62-887b-5dbbc98c377b.jpg\"></p><p>Stay updated with the most important <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/news\">cryptocurrency news</a> and valuable insights, conveniently delivered to your email every day. <a rel=\"noopener noreferrer nofollow\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://mailchi.mp/tokeninsight/newsletter\">Subscribe to the TokenInsight mailing list now!</a></p><p>Prefer social media?             "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",

            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, re-staking protocol EigenLayer plans to adopt a \"shared security\" system, a mechanism allowing protocols to join the network by leveraging a common pool of ETH stakes.</p><p>EigenLayer offers a protocol for users to deposit and \"re-stake\" ether from various liquid staking tokens, aiming to allocate those funds to secure third-party networks. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism. This would make it economically unviable for an attacker to take down any given protocol.</p>",

            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",

            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, re-staking protocol EigenLayer plans to adopt a \"shared security\" system, a mechanism allowing protocols to join the network by leveraging a common pool of ETH stakes.</p><p>EigenLayer offers a protocol for users to deposit and \"re-stake\" ether from various liquid staking tokens, aiming to allocate those funds to secure third-party networks. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism.             "timestamp": 1703673351000,
            "title": "Hong Kong Releases Consultation Paper to Regulate Stablecoins",
            "content": "<p>Hong Kong has released a consultation paper to regulate fiat-referenced stablecoin, with issuers will need to obtain a specific local license. The consultation paper is published today by the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.</p><p>The consultation period for the proposal begins today and will run until February 29, 2024. The proposal outlines the definition of fiat-referenced stablecoins and introduces a requirement for companies that actively promote the issuance of such stablecoins to the public of Hong Kong to obtain a license from the HKMA.</p><p>To obtain an HKMA license, companies will need to meet specific criteria. This includes ensuring that all circulating stablecoins are fully backed by reserves that are at least equal to their par value. Additionally, the proposal emphasizes the need for segregation and safekeeping of reserve assets, as well as regular disclosure and reporting. It is important to note that algorithmic stablecoins will not be eligible for a license under these regulations.</p><p>Furthermore, stablecoin issuers will be required to establish a registered office in Hong Kong and have a chief executive, senior management team, and key personnel in place.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/hk_stables.jpg",

In the future, stATOM may appear on other non-Cosmos DEXes and potentially serve as collateral for non-Cosmos applications.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://tokeninsight.com/en/cryptocurrencies\">TokenInsight</a> is dedicated to covering the most important and cutting-edge trends in the world of crypto.             "content": "<p>Reported by The Defiant, Liquid restaking protocol EtherFi has launched ‘deVamp’ in a bid to incentivize users to swap their existing Eigenlayer deposits for its eETH liquid restaking token (LRT).</p><p>Users that restaked Lido’s stETH, Coinbase’s cbETH, and Binance’s wBETH on Eigenlayer can now instantly swap their deposits into liquid eETH, avoiding the 7-day delay on withdrawals put in place by the highly anticipated restaking protocol.</p><p>With deVamp, users will receive 3,000 loyalty points per restaked ETH migrated into eETH.</p><p>Additionally, holders of these liquid staking tokens (LSTs) can swap them for eETH and earn points on the deVamp website. Traders will be exempt from paying trading fees and earn 2,000 points per ETH.</p><p>Participants in deVamp will receive Vamp Badges, whereas those trying to game the system by depositing and immediately withdrawing will receive a sad pepe Quitter badge with a penalty of 4,000 points upon withdrawal.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/etherfi_vampire.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/liquid-restaking-protocol-etherfi-launched-vampire-attack-strategy?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          },
          {
            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/8-ethereum-validators-went-down-on-sunday-sparking-worries-on-client-diversity?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          }

            "title": "EigenLayer Restake Opens Feb. 6, Removes All LST Caps",
            "content": "<p>Ethereum restaking protocol EigenLayer says it will introduce three new LSTs into the EigenLayer restaking ecosystem: sfrxETH, mETH and LsETH, and is removing the 200,000 ETH cap on LSTs.</p><p>In addition, the team is introducing a new way to distribute restaking points that will cap the amount of restaking points that can be distributed to any one LST, LRT or individual depositor to 33% of the total issuance going forward.</p><p>The team will open the restaking window from February 5th 12pm PT to 9th 12pm PT with the new LSTs sfrxETH, mETH and LsETH and no cap on any LST, after which all deposits will once again be paused.</p>",

            "title": "Liquid Restaking Protocol EtherFi Launched Vampire Attack Strategy",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Defiant, Liquid restaking protocol EtherFi has launched ‘deVamp’ in a bid to incentivize users to swap their existing Eigenlayer deposits for its eETH liquid restaking token (LRT).</p><p>Users that restaked Lido’s stETH, Coinbase’s cbETH, and Binance’s wBETH on Eigenlayer can now instantly swap their deposits into liquid eETH, avoiding the 7-day delay on withdrawals put in place by the highly anticipated restaking protocol.</p><p>With deVamp, users will receive 3,000 loyalty points per restaked ETH migrated into eETH.</p><p>Additionally, holders of these liquid staking tokens (LSTs) can swap them for eETH and earn points on the deVamp website. Traders will be exempt from paying trading fees and earn 2,000 points per ETH.</p><p>Participants in deVamp will receive Vamp Badges, whereas those trying to game the system by depositing and immediately withdrawing will receive a sad pepe Quitter badge with a penalty of 4,000 points upon withdrawal.</p>",

          },
          {
            "timestamp": 1706077463000,
            "title": "Uma Protocol Introduced Oval Allows DeFi Protocols to Capture Oracle Extractable Value",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, blockchain project Uma has rolled out a solution called Oval, which aims to allow DeFi protocols to capture value that emerges during oracle updates by tapping into what’s known as oracle extractable value — a type of MEV generated when protocols request price updates from an oracle.</p><p>MEV involves extracting value by manipulating transaction order in a block on the Ethereum network, often with the aid of automated bots. This type of MEV arises either from the lack of liquidity across different decentralized exchanges or from their front-running each other under certain market conditions.</p><p>There is one type of MEV related to oracles, as Uma notes. In the decentralized finance niche — and in protocols such as lending or borrowing — oracles are crucial as they provide external data, like price feeds, to smart contracts. When an oracle update occurs, such as a price feed update, it can create MEV opportunities. For instance, if a lending protocol relies on an oracle for the latest asset prices, there may be a brief window post-update where a trader can leverage this information before the market responds.</p><p>“MEV is a major issue for Ethereum, with tens of millions of dollars extracted every year. OEV accounts for a big chunk of that because protocols need price updates,” Uma co-founder Hart Lambur said. “Oval addresses a real problem by helping protocols capture OEV. It’s been a privilege to work with Flashbots’ best-in-class team to bring Oval to mainnet.”</p><p>Oval's goal is to enable protocols, such as lending, to utilize this solution to retain and profit from this value rather than losing it to bots. In this setup, MEV searchers participate in an auction system, bidding for the right to access data from Chainlink oracles related to a certain protocol. The auction proceeds then benefit the protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/oval.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/uma-protocol-introduced-oval-allows-defi-protocols-to-capture-oracle-extractable-value?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          },
          {
            "timestamp": 1706065346000,
            "title": "DeBank's Rabby Wallet Launched Points Program, Initial Points Dropped to All Ethereum Address",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Defiant, Rabby, a Web3 wallet launched in 2021 by the popular data platform DeBank, is the latest project to launch a points program to incentivize usage of its browser extension and desktop app.</p><p>Initial points have been dropped to all Ethereum addresses and can be claimed by installing Rabby, importing the wallets, and signing a gasless transaction.</p><p>Rabby is looking to draw users away from Metamask, the leading crypto wallet, by offering up to 12,000 bonus points to those who have used Metamask Swap in the past 12 months.</p><p>Under the new program, users can earn daily points for referring friends, swapping, and using Rabby’s gas top-up feature.</p><p>Web3 projects have increasingly turned to points programs to attract users and capital. By completing certain tasks, users earn points, which generally translate to future token airdrops.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/rabbit.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/debank-s-rabby-wallet-launched-points-program-initial-points-dropped-to-all-ethereum-address?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          },
          {
            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/8-ethereum-validators-went-down-on-sunday-sparking-worries-on-client-diversity?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          }

            "title": "EigenLayer Plans Shared Security Model, Re-stakes to be Used For All Network Services",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, re-staking protocol EigenLayer plans to adopt a \"shared security\" system, a mechanism allowing protocols to join the network by leveraging a common pool of ETH stakes.</p><p>EigenLayer offers a protocol for users to deposit and \"re-stake\" ether from various liquid staking tokens, aiming to allocate those funds to secure third-party networks. The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism. This would make it economically unviable for an attacker to take down any given protocol.</p>",

            "timestamp": 1705980271000,
            "title": "8% Ethereum Validators Went Down on Sunday, Sparking Worries on Client Diversity",
            "content": "<p>Reported by Coindesk, a bug in Ethereum's Nethermind client software – used by validators of the blockchain to interact with the network – knocked out a chunk of the chain's key operators on Sunday.</p><p>It was a manageable incident, but the episode revived a long-simmering debate in the Ethereum ecosystem around the need for \"client diversity.\" Some experts took the opportunity to point out how bad things could have been if another client software, Geth, the chain's most popular execution client, had gone out; the question is whether Ethereum could have kept going since Geth stands out as a possible single point of failure for the network.</p><p>Nethermind powers around 8% of the validators that operate Ethereum, and this weekend's bug was critical enough to pull those validators offline. Ethereum stayed up and running despite the issue, and Nethermind's developers released a patch fixing things within hours. The main consequence of the bug was that modest financial penalties fell onto some Nethermind-based validators.</p><p>Around 85% of Ethereum's validators are currently powered by Geth, and the recent outages to smaller execution clients have renewed concerns that Geth's dominant market position could pose grave consequences if there were ever issues with its programming.</p><p>Depending on the nature of the bug, a Geth glitch could halt the entire network, rendering it impossible for validators to add new blocks to the blockchain. Ethereum is also programmed to penalize validators that fall offline or break the network's rules, meaning thousands of Geth-based validators could be held financially liable in the event of a bug, and the penalties could get even bigger if the bug proves difficult to patch.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/eth_staking2.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/8-ethereum-validators-went-down-on-sunday-sparking-worries-on-client-diversity?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="
          }
        ],

          {
            "timestamp": 1706077463000,
            "title": "Uma Protocol Introduced Oval Allows DeFi Protocols to Capture Oracle Extractable Value",
            "content": "<p>Reported by The Block, blockchain project Uma has rolled out a solution called Oval, which aims to allow DeFi protocols to capture value that emerges during oracle updates by tapping into what’s known as oracle extractable value — a type of MEV generated when protocols request price updates from an oracle.</p><p>MEV involves extracting value by manipulating transaction order in a block on the Ethereum network, often with the aid of automated bots. This type of MEV arises either from the lack of liquidity across different decentralized exchanges or from their front-running each other under certain market conditions.</p><p>There is one type of MEV related to oracles, as Uma notes. In the decentralized finance niche — and in protocols such as lending or borrowing — oracles are crucial as they provide external data, like price feeds, to smart contracts. When an oracle update occurs, such as a price feed update, it can create MEV opportunities. For instance, if a lending protocol relies on an oracle for the latest asset prices, there may be a brief window post-update where a trader can leverage this information before the market responds.</p><p>“MEV is a major issue for Ethereum, with tens of millions of dollars extracted every year. OEV accounts for a big chunk of that because protocols need price updates,” Uma co-founder Hart Lambur said. “Oval addresses a real problem by helping protocols capture OEV. It’s been a privilege to work with Flashbots’ best-in-class team to bring Oval to mainnet.”</p><p>Oval's goal is to enable protocols, such as lending, to utilize this solution to retain and profit from this value rather than losing it to bots. In this setup, MEV searchers participate in an auction system, bidding for the right to access data from Chainlink oracles related to a certain protocol. The auction proceeds then benefit the protocol.</p>",
            "image_url": "https://s2.tokeninsight.com/static/news/cover/img/oval.png",
            "url": "https://tokeninsight.com/en/news/uma-protocol-introduced-oval-allows-defi-protocols-to-capture-oracle-extractable-value?utm_source=public&utm_medium=api&utm_campaign="

            "content": "<p>Synthetix’s native token, SNX, is no longer inflationary following a successful SIP 2043 proposal which stopped the issuance of new tokens.</p><p>$SNX token holders have passed the proposal SIP-2043 to end the issuance of rewards in the form of newly-minted SNX tokens. In the future, Synthetix stakers will only receive rewards from trading fees, with the protocol set to introduce a buy-back and burn mechanism once its Andromeda upgrade is deployed on Base.</p><p>The rationale behind the proposal, published by Synthetix founder Kain Warwick, was that the effectiveness of inflation has diminished over time compared to the initial introduction which worked to incentivise liquidity and bootstrap the protocol. Additionally, the recently proposed buyback and burn experiments would be counter-intuitive if inflation continued.</p><p>The Synthetix team said that SNX will become deflationary following the rollout of Andromeda. Half of the trading fees generated from Andromeda will be used to purchase and burn SNX tokens, with stakers receiving the other 50% of fees as rewards.</p>",

            "title": "Decentralized Sequencer Espresso System Launched Gibraltar Testnet",
            "content": "<p>Decentralized sequencer protocol Espresso system launched fourth testnet, Gibraltar testnet, and is publicly available for Arbitrum developers.</p><p>Layer 2 Sequencers are responsible for processing and ordering transactions from a mempool into blocks. They can be compared to validators on monolithic blockchains or layer-1 networks, and play an important role in securing the network.</p><p>The problem with sequencers today is that many rollups run their own sequencers with their own execution environments, and zero-knowledge solutions run their own provers. Thai introduces trust assumptions and centralization concerns.</p><p>In addition to making it possible for Arbitrum developers to test their dapps using the shared sequencer network, the Gibraltar testnet will also see external node operators run the network for the first time.</p><p>Espresso provides a shared sequencer network, a distributed consensus system shared between rollups — which has so far already been integrated with Optimism, Cartesi and Polygon zkEVM via testnet</p>",

The project's first stage was released on the Ethereum mainnet in June 2023.</p><p>In the future, the team intends to nudge the project into a major decentralized application platform and enable other projects to launch, leveraging the so-called shared security.</p><p>That version will enable the amount of ETH re-stakes on EigenLayer — currently over $1.7 billion — to be supplied to all services developed on the network simultaneously for the sake of a common security mechanism.
